#Text=Richard Coppin
#Text=Richard
#Text=Coppin
#Text=was a seventeenth-century English political and religious writer , and prolific radical pamphleteer and preacher .
#Text=Late 1640s to late 1650s
#Text=He was an Anglican clergyman , until 1648 , [ 1 ] or possibly a lay preacher from Berkshire with little formal education . [ 2 ]
#Text=He is known as an associate of Abiezer Coppe , who wrote an introduction to Coppin 's 1649 Divine Teachings .
#Text=Christopher Hill [ 3 ] considers that Coppe took most of his theology from Coppin .
#Text=After the suppression of episcopacy ( 9 October 1646 ) he had attached himself for a short time to the presbyterians in London .
#Text=He afterwards was an Independent .
#Text=Based on an inward experience in 1648 he was not to exercise a settled ministry .
#Text=He began to preach in Berkshire . [ 4 ]
#Text=He was constantly in trouble , well documented in pamphlets , arising from the 1650 Blasphemy Act . [ 5 ]
#Text=The authorities treated him leniently in the period 1651 to 1655 . [ 6 ]
#Text=He first got into serious trouble by preaching on four successive days in the parish church of Evenlode , Worcestershire .
#Text=He had been invited by parishioners , with the consent of the rector , Ralph Nevil .

#Text=Nevil , however , brought neighbouring clergy to discuss matters with Coppin in the church , and eventually got a warrant against him for blasphemy . Coppin was tried before Chief Baron John Wilde at the Worcester assizes on 23 March 1652 .
#Text=The jury found him guilty of denying heaven and hell ; but Wilde reproved them for their verdict , and bound over Coppin to appear for judgment at the next assize .
#Text=By that time his accusers had fresh evidence , relating to Coppin 's proceedings at Enstone , Oxfordshire , whereupon Judge Nicholes bound him to appear at the next Oxford assize . [ 4 ]
#Text=A debate he had at Burford , Oxfordshire in 1651 was recorded by his counterpart on the side of orthodoxy , John Osborne , vicar of Bampton . [ 7 ] [ 8 ]
#Text=Osborne was a presbyterian , east vicar at Bampton from 1648 to 1662 . [ 9 ]
#Text=On 10 March 1653 he was tried at Oxford before Serjeant Green ; the jury at first disagreed , but eventually found him guilty .
#Text=Green bound him over to the next assize , when Judge Hutton gave him his discharge .
#Text=Preaching at Stow-on-the-Wold , Gloucestershire , on 19 March 1654 , Coppin was again apprehended and brought for trial at Gloucester on informations before Serjeant Glyn on 22 July .
#Text=Glyn would not receive the informations , and so the matter ended . [ 4 ]
#Text=About 1650 , Joseph Salmon , minister in Kent , had set up a course of Sunday preaching in Rochester Cathedral .
#Text=Salmon was an allegorist , and is said to have ' sowed the seeds of ranting familism . ' In midsummer 1655 Salmon went abroad , and his followers brought Coppin from London to fill his place .
#Text=It is probable that his acquaintance with Abiezer Coppe introduced him to the sectaries of Rochester .

#Text=At the end of September or beginning of October 1655 , Walter Rosewell , incumbent of Chatham , went to hear Coppin preach , and gained the impression that he affirmed the peccability of Christ and denied the resurrection of the flesh .
#Text=Rosewell , with other presbyterians , agreed to conduct a Tuesday lecture in the cathedral to counteract Coppin 's heresies .

#Text=A public discussion was held in the cathedral ( from 3 to 13 December ) between Coppin and Rosewell , assisted by Daniel French , minister of Stroud , the mayor presiding ; before it ended , Gaman , an anabaptist , put himself forward to oppose both parties .
#Text=On Saturday night , 22 December , Coppin was served with a warrant forbidding him to preach next day , and requiring his attendance before the magistrates on Monday .
#Text=He preached , not in the cathedral , where a guard of soldiers was set , but in the college-yard , and in the fields . [ 4 ]
#Text=He was imprisoned on 24 December 1655 as a Ranter , [ 10 ] a term which is now contested in historiography . [ 11 ]
#Text=Thomas Kelsey , one of Cromwell 's major-generals then based at Dover , took a harder line with Coppin than previously , [ 10 ] imposing six months in jail .
#Text=He defended himself , writing from Maidstone Prison a pamphlet A Blow at the Serpent .
#Text=Another account was that of Walter Rosewell , pushed out as vicar at Chatham , Kent in 1649 , [ 12 ] in The serpents subtilty discovered . [ 13 ]
#Text=Before 26 June 1656 he had been set free by habeas corpus . [ 4 ]
#Text=Coppin 's work provoked Edward Garland , vicar at Hartclip ( Hartlip , Kent ) , to reply in kind in 1657 , [ 14 ] accusing Coppin of heresies .
#Text=The pamphlet exchange was extended by Coppin 's Michael opposing the dragon ( 1659 ) .
#Text=Legacy
#Text=Coppin and Gerard Winstanley both preached universal salvation ; and both began to publish in the same year , 1649 .
#Text=The universalist views of their contemporary , Jeremy White , were not published till 1712 .
#Text=Coppin deals moderately with his opponents .
#Text=His followers seem to have formed a sect ; the tenets of ' the Copinists ' were later given by S. Rogers ( The Post-Boy robb 'd of His Mail , 2nd ed . 1706 , p.428 ) .
#Text=Later he found an admirer in Cornelius Cayley , and a critic in James Relly , a universalist of another type ( see his ' The Sadducee detected , ' &c . 1764 ) . [ 4 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=Divine Teachings ( 1649 )
#Text=The Exaltation of All Things in Christ ( 1649 )
#Text=Man 's Righteousnesse Examined ( 1652 )
#Text=Saul Smitten for not Smiting Amalek ( 1653 )
#Text=A Man-Child Born ( 1654 )
#Text=Truths testimony and a testimony of truths ( 1655 )
#Text=A Blow at the Serpent ( 1656 )
#Text=Crux Christi ( 1657 )
#Text=Michael opposing the dragon ( 1659 )
#Text=Views
#Text=He believed in universal salvation , [ 15 ] [ 16 ] the possibility of return to the state before the Fall of Man , [ 17 ] and the equality of women . [ 18 ]
#Text=He treated the Fall and Last Judgment as allegories , [ 19 ] and was dismissive of the established church [ 20 ] and universities . [ 21 ]
#Text=He is sometimes presented as a ' moderate ' Ranter , [ 22 ] or philosopher of Ranterism . [ 23 ] Christopher Hill shaded his opinion to ' near-Ranter ' .
#Text=Notes and references
